facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 215 of 1955 filed against judgment of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 215 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 1, 1953, of the Calcutta High Court

facts.text: Calcutta High Court judgment and decree dated April 1, 1953 in Appeal from Original Decree No. 89 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 1, 1953, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 89 of 1946, arising,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Darjeeling, judgment and decree dated December 4, 1945 in Money Suit No. 5 of 1940.

anchor.surface_text: arising, out of the judgment and decree dated December 4, 1945, of the Subordinate Judge, Darjeeling, in Money Suit No. 5 of 1940. K. Jha and D. N.

facts.text: Appellant Gherulal Parakh and first respondent Mahadeodas Maiya, managers of two joint families, entered into partnership for wagering contracts.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Gherulal Parakh, and the first respondent, Mahadeodas Maiya, managers of two joint families entered into a partnership to carry on wagering contracts with two firms of Hapur, namely, Messrs. Mulchand Gulzarimull and Baldeosahay Surajmull.

facts.text: Partnership to carry on wagering contracts with Messrs. Mulchand Gulzarimull and Baldeosahay Surajmull of Hapur.

anchor.surface_text: managers of two joint families entered into a partnership to carry on wagering contracts with two firms of Hapur, namely, Messrs. Mulchand Gulzarimull and Baldeosahay Surajmull. It was agreed between the partners

facts.text: Contracts made in name of respondents on behalf of firm, profit and loss borne equally.

anchor.surface_text: It was agreed between the partners that the said contracts would be made in the name of the respondents on behalf of the firm and that the profit and loss resulting from the transactions would be borne by them in equal shares.

facts.text: First respondent entered into 32 contracts with Mulchand and 49 with Baldeosahay.

anchor.surface_text: In implementation of the said agreement, the first respondent entered into 32 contracts with Mulchand and 49 contracts with Baldeosahay and the nett result of all these transactions was a loss,

facts.text: Net result of transactions was a loss, first respondent paid entire amount to Hapur merchants.

anchor.surface_text: and 49 contracts with Baldeosahay and the nett result of all these transactions was a loss, with the result that the first respondent had to pay to the Hapur merchants the entire amount due to them.

facts.text: Appellant denied liability to bear share of loss.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellant denied his liability to bear his share of the loss, the first respondent along With his sons filed O. S. No. 18 of 1937

facts.text: First respondent and sons filed O.S. No. 18 of 1937 in Subordinate Judge, Darjeeling for half loss in Mulchand transactions.

anchor.surface_text: the first respondent along With his sons filed O. S. No. 18 of 1937 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Darjeeling, for the recovery of half of the loss incurred in the transactions with Mulchand.

facts.text: O.S. No. 18/1937 referred to arbitration, decree for Rs. 3,375.

anchor.surface_text: That suit was referred to arbitration and on the basis of the award, the Subordinate Judge made a decree in favour of the first respondent and his sons for a sum of Rs. 3,375.

facts.text: Present suit instituted by first respondent for Rs. 5,300 with interest after final accounts settled.

anchor.surface_text: After the final accounts were settled between the first respondent and the two merchants of Hapur and after the amounts due to them were paid, the first respondent instituted a suit,

facts.text: Plaint amended to claim relief on basis of dissolved firm.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the plaint was amended and by the amended plaint the respondents asked for the same relief on the basis that the firm had been dissolved.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed suit, found agreement void under s.23 Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge found that the agreement between the parties was to enter into wagering contracts depending upon the rise and fall of the market and that the said agreement was void as the said object was forbidden by law and opposed to public policy.

facts.text: High Court held partnership between two managers, valid; single venture, dissolved after season; decreed Rs. 3,807-8-0.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the learned Judges of the High Court held that the partnership was not between the two joint families but was only between the two managers of the said families and therefore it was valid. They found that the partnership to do business was only for a single venture

facts.text: Transactions between March 23, 1937, and June 17, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: the plaint discloses that the parties jointly entered into contracts with two merchants between March 23, 1937, and June 17, 1937,

facts.text: High Court found first respondent paid Rs. 7,615 on Baldeosahay losses.

anchor.surface_text: They further found that the object of the partnership was to deal in differences and that though the said transactions, being in the nature of wager, were void under s. 30 of the Indian Contract Act,

facts.text: Suit filed for recovery of Rs. 4,146-4-3 being half of total payments.

anchor.surface_text: that they issued a notice to the defendants to pay them a sum of Rs. 4,146-4-3, being half of the total payments made by them on account of the said contracts

facts.text: Defendant filed written statement on June 12, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed for recovery of the said amount. The defendant filed a written-statement on June 12, 1940,

facts.text: Additional written statement on November 9, 1941 raising s.69 Partnership Act.

anchor.surface_text: but did not raise the plea based on s. 69 of the Partnership Act. He filed an additional written-statement on November 9, 1941, expressly setting up the plea.

facts.text: Plaint amended on November 17, 1941 alleging dissolution.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the plaintiffs prayed for the amendment of the, plaint by adding the following to the plaint as paragraph That even Section 69 of the Indian Partnership Act is not a bar

facts.text: Further additional written statement on August 14, 1942 denying dissolution.

anchor.surface_text: On August 14, 1942, the defendant filed a further additional written-statement alleging that the allegations in paragraph 2 were not true

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts partnership for forward contracts during particular season, dissolved by completion.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from the said findings that the partnership was only in respect of forward contracts with two specified individuals and for a particular season.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds wagering transactions with no intention to deliver goods.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts, on the evidence, both direct and circumstantial, came to the conclusion that the partnership agreement was entered into with the object of carrying on wagering transactions wherein there was no intention to ask for-or to take delivery of goods but only to deal with differences.

issues.text: the question of the legality of a partnership to carry on business in wagering contracts

anchor.surface_text: This appeal filed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta raises the question of the legality of a partnership to carry on business in wagering contracts.

issues.text: whether the said agreement of partnership is unlawful within the meaning of s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act

anchor.surface_text: whether the said agreement of partnership is unlawful within the meaning of s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act. Section 23 of the said Act, omitting portions unnecessary for the present purpose, reads as follows The consideration or object of an agreement is lawful, unless- it is forbidden by law, or the Court regards it as immoral, or opposed to public policy.

issues.text: whether the suit was barred under s. 69(1) of the Partnership Act

anchor.surface_text: the partnership was not registered, the suit was barred under s. 69(1) of the Partnership Act and that in any event the suit was barred under S. 2, Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The learned Subordinate Judge found that the agreement between the parties was to enter into wagering contracts depending upon the rise and fall of the market and that the said agreement was void as the said object was forbidden by law and opposed to public policy.

issues.text: whether the suit was barred under S. 2, Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure

anchor.surface_text: the suit was barred under S. 2, Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The learned Subordinate Judge found that the agreement between the parties was to enter into wagering contracts depending upon the rise and fall of the market and that the said agreement was void as the said object was forbidden by law and opposed to public policy. He also found that the claim in respect of the transactions with Mulchand so far as it was not included in the earlier suit was not barred under s. 2, Rule 2, Code of Civil Procedure,

issues.text: whether what is void under s. 30 can be equated with what is forbidden by law within the meaning of s. 23

anchor.surface_text: As a contract which provides for payment of differences only without any intention on the part of either of the parties to give or take delivery of the goods is admittedly a wager within the meaning of s. 30 of the Contract Act, the argument proceeds, such a transaction, being void under the said section, is also forbidden by law within the meaning of s. 23 of the Contract Act. The question, shortly stated, is whether what is void can be equated with what is forbidden by law.

issues.text: whether the object of the partnership is opposed to public policy

anchor.surface_text: or the Court regards it as immoral, or opposed to public policy. In each of these cases, the consideration or object of an agreement is said to be unlawful. Every agreement of which the object or consideration is unlawful is void. Under this section, the object of an agreement, whether it is of partnership or otherwise, is unlawful if it is forbidden by law or the Court regards it as immoral or opposed to public policy

issues.text: whether the object of the partnership is immoral

anchor.surface_text: or the Court regards it as immoral, or opposed to public policy. The learned Counsel for the appellant advances his argument under three sub-heads (i) the object is forbidden by law, (ii) it is opposed to public policy, and (iii) it is immoral.

issues.text: If so, s. 42 of the Partnership Act directly applies to this case

anchor.surface_text: If so, s. 42 of the Partnership Act directly applies to this case. Under that section in the absence of a contract to the contrary, a firm is dissolved, if it is constituted to carry out one or more adventures or undertakings, by completion thereof.

holdings.text: s. 42 of the Partnership Act directly applies to this case. Under that section in the absence of a contract to the contrary, a firm is dissolved, if it is constituted to carry out one or more adventures or undertakings, by completion thereof.

anchor.surface_text: If so, s. 42 of the Partnership Act directly applies to this case. Under that section in the absence of a contract to the contrary, a firm is dissolved, if it is constituted to carry out one or more adventures or undertakings, by completion thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings establish partnership limited to forward contracts with specific merchants for one season; completion of transactions dissolves firm automatically under s42.

holdings.text: the partnership agreement was entered into with the object of carrying on wagering transactions wherein there was no intention to ask for-or to take delivery of goods but only to deal with differences. That is a concurrent finding of fact, and, following the usual practice of this Court, we must accept it.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts, on the evidence, both direct and circumstantial, came to the conclusion that the partnership agreement was entered into with the object of carrying on wagering transactions wherein there was no intention to ask for-or to take delivery of goods but only to deal with differences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts concurrent findings of lower courts based on direct and circumstantial evidence.

holdings.text: what is void can be equated with what is forbidden by law... This argument is not a new one, but has been raised... and has uniformly been rejected... s. 30 of the Indian Contract Act is based upon the provisions of s. 18 of the Gaming Act, 1845, and though a wager is void and unenforceable, it is not forbidden by law

anchor.surface_text: As a contract which provides for payment of differences only without any intention on the part of either of the parties to give or take delivery of the goods is admittedly a wager within the meaning of s. 30 of the Contract Act, the argument proceeds, such a transaction, being void under the said section, is also forbidden by law within the meaning of s. 23

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes void (unenforceable) under s30 from forbidden/illegal under s23; extensive review of English (Gaming Acts, cases like Thacker v Hardy) and Indian precedents uniformly rejecting equation; collateral contracts enforceable.

holdings.text: there is no principle of public policy has been evolved or recognized invalidating wagers.

anchor.surface_text: or the Court regards it as immoral, or opposed to public policy. In each of these cases, the consideration or object of an agreement is said to be unlawful. Every agreement of which the object or consideration is unlawful is void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evolved principle in English common law or Indian law against wagers; history shows enforcement pre-1845, void but collaterals enforceable post; legislatures did not declare illegal; Hindu texts not enforced; doctrine invoked only in clear incontestable harm cases.

holdings.text: The only aspect of immorality with which Court of Law have dealt is sexual immorality.

anchor.surface_text: or the Court regards it as immoral, or opposed to public policy. The learned Counsel for the appellant advances his argument under three sub-heads (i) the object is forbidden by law, (ii) it is opposed to public policy, and (iii) it is immoral.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Immorality under s23 confined to sexual immorality per English and Indian authorities; wagering not within scope.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that in the present case the partnership is not unlawful within the meaning of s. 23 of the Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: If so, s. 42 of the Partnership Act directly applies to this case. Under that section in the absence of a contract to the contrary, a firm is dissolved, if it is constituted to carry out one or more adventures or undertakings, by completion thereof.

anchor.surface_text: or the Court regards it as immoral, or opposed to public policy. In each of these cases, the consideration or object of an agreement is said to be unlawful. Every agreement of which the object or consideration is unlawful is void.
